body: Can you try the `dev` branch once #7677 has been merged in?

I can of course test that branch once the fix is merged, but after reading the bug report and the intended fix, I do not see this as related to my issue. I am having a security issue thrown by the browser because of mismatch origins. the browser doesnt allow `ipc://` fetch in an `https://` page. Even when adding CSP to the https page. As far as I understood the bug and fix you refer to, it is not the same issue.

Ok I understand you need a macos test of your fix, even though it is unrelated to my issue. Let me know once the merge is done on `next`, and i ll introduce an `options` argument in one of my commands to test it. That's fine!

And I understood everybody else is on vacation, so I ll wait for my own issue to be reviewed.

Seems like this only impacts macOS, WKWebView does some extended checks to prevent HTTPS to fetch a weird protocol :(
We'll fallback to the postMessage IPC in this case.

nice to see a fix already @lucasfernog . I will test it in the coming days.
2 comments :
- if WKWebView is the problem, then you should probably exclude also ios target, right?
- so if the new IPC mechanism doesn't work for linux, android, ios and mac, then... it only works for windows, right ?

Not really, if you have a recent version of webkit2gtk installed (which is just a matter of time before it is available in all distros) and you enabled `linux-ipc-protocol` feature flag, and you're not using remote URLs on macOS and iOS, then you have windows, macos, ios and linux support.

I will open another PR to extend this for iOS and also fix the channel response usage.

The new IPC is used on all platforms, even if it's just to send bigger responses to speed up the process. It's just a little bit slower on Linux and Android (plus remote URLs on Apple) but it's still a lot faster than v1 IPC.

Thanks for the clarification ! 
I will test all of that once the new PR will be coded and merged. Thanks!
Hello @lucasfernog, any news about the new PR ?
@nikoPLP the fix has been released, can you try with latest alpha?

Yes all is good for me with the latest release (tauri alpha.14, api alpha.8)
I tested on all platforms, except iOS for which I don't have yet a dev env.
Thank you very much!

issue.title: fix(ipc): fallback to postMessage if protocol fails, closes #8476

repository.name: tauri
repository.description: Build smaller, faster, and more secure desktop and mobile applications with a web frontend.

issue.body:
This PR changes the IPC mechanism to always support the custom-protocol and postMessage variants. The frontend now handles the custom protocol fetch call failing (usually due to CSP or webview denying access to the protocol) and fallbacks to the postMessage API).

The fixes for #7662 (#7751, #7754 and #7764) are still valid.

This is a more generic approach to #8887

body: I have this issue too, would be nice to just override and specify https:// protocol from the get go, very confusing errors. Will try no-ipc-custom-protocol

issue.title: Tauri spike

labels.name: easy
labels.description: Trivial to do (even when tired!) and semi-worthwhile

labels.name: Tauri
labels.description: Bug that appears to be Tauri specific

issue.body: Explore [Tauri](https://v2.tauri.app/). This is something I actually started doing on Thursday, July 10th. I was curious as to whether Tauri might be viable for stepping-stone native client (and possibly server) implementations for macOS, iOS, Android and Windows. I've gotten far enough that I've created this issue to track my work, especially since I will probably do this in little chunks here and there in between other things and may have to totally put this on the back-burner when [teaching issues](https://github.com/ctm/mb2-doc/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aopen%20label%3Ateaching) become high priority In the above screen-shot, the foreground window is a native macOS mb2 app. In the background is my browser, also running mb2. They're both connected to an mb2 server running locally, but they are talking to each other. This shows that the way I use WebSockets works under Tauri as does the general UI. - [ ] Client - [ ] Review [setup notes](https://v2.tauri.app/develop/) - [x] logging - [ ] macOS - [x] Lobby - [x] WebSockets - [x] Change POC into acceptable for production code - [x] See if edition and version can be changed - [x] Figure a platform-agnostic way to find the wasm file - [x] See whether fetch can be used (we currently hit the server, but don't get a response we can use) - [x] Figure out if we can reload the wasm file in a way to get updates - [x] Figure out what to do about `mb2_commands::protcol_host_and_port` (probably conditional compilation) - [x] Table - [x] Opening a New Window - [ ] Pop-out chat - [x] Pop-out - [ ] Pop-in - [ ] By closing pop-out chat window - [ ] By clicking on "Pop-in" - [x] Bring window to the front - [x] Title - [x] Reopening windows - [x] Links in chat - [x] Rulebook pages - [x] Make it so dev goes to localhost but build goes to craftpoker.com - [x] Start using it to play the evening tournaments - [ ] iOS - [x] Build System - [x] commenting out inappropriate (i.e., window resizing) code - [x] using conditional compilation to excise inappropriate code - [x] WebSockets - [ ] Single page refactor - [ ] Signing - [ ] Android - [x] Build System - [x] commenting out inappropriate (i.e., window resizing) code - [x] using conditional compilation to excise inappropriate code - [x] WebSockets - [ ] Windows - [ ] Server
